div.p: Mr Montandon brought back the Clock I had given him to repair, and took my Chronometer to clean— As it has twice stopped I can place no reliance upon it, until the cause of its irregularity shall be removed— Thumlert is the man who has been to me several times, and who is yet unable to authenticate the marriage and deaths of his father and mother, and his own birth. He now brought a Letter from himself to Daniel Crommelin and Son at Amsterdam, containing a statements of facts, with copies of two certificates, one from the Clerk of the County Court at Baltimore that in Novr. 1782. a licence was issued from that Court to a German Clergyman named, to marry John Martin Thumlert and Miller, and the other from the present minister of the German Lutheran Church at Baltimore, that the person named in the above certificate was at that time Pastor of that Church— But he has no positive Evidence of the Marriage, and no evidence either of the deaths or births— He had also signed the Letter as well for his brother George, who he says lives at Philadelphia, as for himself. I advised him to take back his Letter and strike out the name of his brother from the signature; and add to it that authenticated copies of the Certificates will be forwarded if necessary. And I said I would then send the Letter through Mr Hughes, our Charge d’Affaires to the Netherlands, who he says must have known his father at Annapolis— Governor Barbour and Mr Clay were here together— The Governor had a Letter from a friend of his named Stewart who has been for thirty years or more, one of the Electors of President and Vice President; and who gives him some account of electioneering movements in Virginia, favourable to the Administration, and some advice to avoid controvertible matter in the Message to Congress— Which I told the Governor I was disposed to do; believing that the first, and perhaps the last of my annual Messages would be the only occasions proper for an avowal of general principles. Mr Clay spoke of the despatches last received from Mr Gallatin, which inform us that he has agreed upon another Convention with the British Government, which is to regulate the reference to a friendly Sovereign of the question relating to the North-eastern boundary. He said Mr Gallatin would come home—and that he regretted his omission to present the formal claim of our right to navigate the St. Lawrence river— Dr. Hagan came to apply for an appointment of Surgeon’s mate in the army, and brought with him several Letters of recommendation— I took a walk of three hours in the woods—gathering Acorns, and few Nuts— The white Oak Acorns are in great plenty, lying on the ground, and have almost all germinated. All others are exceedingly scarce, and I found not one that had germinated. I went particularly to seek for acorns of the Post Oak, and found a few, upon and under several trees— But they are very small. I also discovered westward of the rear of the College, growing nearly together, three Willow Oaks—two of them beautiful trees at least forty feet high, and nine or ten feet in circumference. Their acorns, of which I gathered a handful, some upon the ground and some from the trees, are still smaller than those of the Post-Oak— Their leaves have begun to fall, but those upon the trees are yet green; as are those of the black and grey Oaks—while those of the white Oaks have turned to the darkest crimson— I found three unknown seeds which I propose to plant, and gathered two Persimons— This fruit is sometimes eaten; but is in so little esteem, that the boys and the negroes, are not even tempted to pluck them from the trees— They are hanging thick upon them the leaves having all fallen— Johnson Hellen and John, returned this Evening from Rockville— Mrs Adams removed from her Bedchamber, down to the room on the first floor.
2. IV. Walk over Tyber.

Mistaking Moonlight for the dawn, I rose this morning at 4. O’Clock and after writing the Diary of Yesterday, found time for an hours walk before Breakfast— Mr Dickens came, and took back the proof sheet of his circular as Secretary to the Columbian Institute, in which I had made some verbal alterations— He readily adopted them and spoke of the employment of a Gardener to attend occasionally at the garden of the Institute— There is little to do, and a man had been employed, at the price of 5. dollars a Month— But he died last Summer, and Mr Foy the Gardener at the Capitol had offered if I should express the wish that he should, to superintend the Garden, and to employ an occasional workman by the day as might be needed—which I approved— At one O’Clock I went into the Woods with my Son John, to gather Acorns and Nuts for planting. In ranging nearly three hours through the forest, I found upon the ground a great profusion of Chesnut Oak and White Oak Acorns, and scarcely one other— Of the Post-Oak and Black Jack, which I was particularly solicitous to obtain, although I found multitudes of the Trees, I did not obtain a single Acorn— Very few of the Black, grey and Spanish Oaks, the trees of which abound but none of them appear to be in bearing— We gathered about a peck of the white and Chesnut Oak Acorns, and might have gathered bushels. They differ very much in size, upon different trees; and the size of the acorn is not at all proportioned to that of the tree— Some of the Chesnut Oak are of the largest size, and equal to the Acorns of the English Oak— They also differ somewhat in form some being more oblong, and some oblate—approaching the shape of the Black Oak Acorn— We also gathered a few Persimmons for the seed— They are not yet all ripe, although there have several successive Nights of Sharp frost. I found also a few Shag barks a few pignuts but not more than three or four Chesnuts— The Acorns have almost all germinated— They should be gathered the las week in September, and first week in October. While we were out, the Revd. Messrs.Hawley, Bedell and Milnor, and Ridgely called to see me. I signed Orders for the appointment of Judah Williams as Light House keeper on Tibbet’s point Lake Ontario, New-York with a Salary of 350 dollars a year; and of Richard F. Fox, as Keeper of the floating light at Hooper’s Straits in the Chesapeake Bay, Maryland, with a Salary of 500 dollars a year— I began this Evening the draft of my third Annual Message to Congress, and immediately found the want of minutes from the Department of State— I read with much pleasure Mr Binney’s Eulogium upon the late Chief-Justice Tilghman of Pennsylvania.
3. IV:30. Walk to the woods—

After writing the Journal of yesterday, I sallied out to the woods in further search of Acorns— As in my former attempts I found a great plenty of the white Oak; but none of the kinds which I specially sought— I went again to the willow Oaks, which I had discovered the other day, and gathered under them a few more of their Acorns, the very diminutive size of which leads me to doubt whether the germinating principle is in them, which on the other the Majestic growth and beauty of the trees indicate that they are entirely congenial to this soil and climate— I found nothing else, and was much annoyed by rain the whole time I was out.

The Reverend Mr Phillips is a young Clergyman from South-Carolina who introduced himself and who told me he was returning from an excursion to the North— Mr Pleasonton came and took with him the orders for the appointment of Light house keepers which I had signed yesterday, and also those for the appointment of Francis Elberson keeper of the Light-House on the Brandywine Shoal, with a Salary of 500 dollars a year— Of Isaac Dunham, keeper of the Light-House on Pemaquid Point in Maine, with a Salary of 350 dollars a year—and of John O’Neil, keeper of the Light House at Concord Point, Maryland, with a Salary of 350 dollars a year, which I signed this day— He took also the deep files of applications and recommendations for these appointments, with the exception of a few of the papers which I had not yet read— Coll. Roberdeau called with Mr Davy, who is a Son of our Consul at Hull, lately deceased; and who has come over from England, for the purpose of soliciting the appointment in his father’s place— I asked Roberdeau if he had seen Captain Basil Hall’s Letter published in a Boston paper recommending the observation of certain occultations of fixed Stars till the 8th. of next Month. He said he had heard of it but not seen it— I urged him to procure it, and to get Mr Elliot to make the observations, which he said he would. He spoke of an Astronomical Clock made by Willard, which Mr Elliot had ordered, and which had arrived at Alexandria but for which Elliot could not now pay being called upon to pay endorsements for the late Mr Little, and thus in great embarassment. I desired Coll. Roberdeau to ask Mr Elliot to have the Clock sent to me— I would pay for it, and keep it until it might suit Mr Elliot’s convenience to take it. I spoke to him of Montandon, who he said was undoubtably a skilful artist, and he would be glad to employ him to put in order the Clocks and Chronometers at the War Department— Gouverneur and Ringgold came together— Gouverneur is returning with his wife, from Mr Monroe’s at Oakhill to New-York. Mr Rush came with sundry papers upon business; particularly upon a claim of the Brothers Baring at London, for a payment to Russell and La Farge at Havre, on Account of furniture for the President’s House, furnished in 1817. upon an order from Coll. Lane, professedly accompanied with a remittance of 3000 dollars to James H. M’Culloch, Collector at Baltimore, with order to remit the amount to the Baring’s— But which remittance, Lane appears not to have made. We agreed that the claim of the Baring’s must be paid, but the question remains from what fund the money can now be drawn. Mr Johnston merely called to pay a morning visit— Mr Brent came and took back all the papers that Mr Forrest had left with me, prepared for the new Register. Governor Barbour left with me a voluminous record of the proceedings of a Court Martial upon the trial of Assistant Surgeon Thomas Sydenham Bryant. The Revd. Messrs.Allen, Bedell, Hawley, and Milnor, and Mr Rush dined with us. I received Letters from my Sons George and Charles.

list.item: Frye. N. and Mrs and Tom

div.p:
Mrs Stewart is an old widow Lady, with a family of grown up children—several daughters and two Sons— One of whom is employed in the Indian Agency in the Territory of Michigan, and the other, was a Clerk in the Department of War. She came to me this morning in great distress; and shewed me a Letter from the Secretary of War, to him who was the Clerk; simply saying in two lines that his Services were no longer required in that Department. She complained in the agony of her heart, that this dismission had been sent abruptly, and without a word of previous notice to her Son, who was now, and had been for several days confined to his bed with sickness— That she had yesterday morning gone herself to the War Department; to give notice of this cause of her Sons absence; and was met by his terrible
notification— That she had seen the Secretary of War, and was informed by him, that the cause of her Son’s dimission was intemperance— That she had told the Secretary that the cause of her Sons absence from the Office now was sickness—which Governor Barbour said he had not known— That she had intreated him to reinstate her Son whose Salary was almost her only dependence for her support and that of her daughters— The Governor told her it was too late, as he had already disposed of the Office to Mr Taylor, late a member of Congress from Virginia. She therefore implored me to speak to the other heads of Departments in behalf of her Son, for any vacancy of a Clerkship that may occur or any occasional employment that may be wanted— She said she was a relation, a second Cousin of Mr Monroe, at whose instance this appointment had been given to her Son, upon the express understanding that the Salary should be applied to her support and that of her family— That her Rent was now due, and she was indebted for ten Cords of Wood, purchased for her winter’s supply. She knew not where to look for the means of payment, her son’s Salary being cut off. He was a kind and affectionate Son. He was also as faithful and efficient a Clerk as any one in the Department, though he was occasionally imprudent—but it did not often happen. Sometimes not for Months together, then only for a few days; followed by the severest penitence— She had last fall spoken of it to Governor Barbour, and intreated him to bear with her Sons infirmity— She had promised as far as she was able to reclaim him, and she had great influence over him— But his head was weak, a Single glass would unsettle him; and then without knowing what he was about, he would drink more. But he had been treated more harshly than others, and she named to me three or four persons, who she said had killed themselves with liquor, who had yet been suffered to retain their offices till the last days of their lives, and then they had been given to their Children— I told her that I would speak to the heads of Departments, of her Son; but it could only be an expression of my feelings. The appointment of Clerks was by law vested in the Heads of the Respective Departments; and they appointed and displaced them under their own responsibility and often without consulting at all the President. Governor Barbour had not mentioned to me his dimssion of Mr Stewart or its cause— And I myself had once been compelled to dismiss a Clerk from the Department of State for the same cause; and had done it without consulting Mr Monroe. Mrs Stewart also pleaded with me in behalf of her Son, in Michigan, who she says has no vice, and is now upon a Salary of only 500 dollars a year— I heard this morning at St. John’s Church Mr Bedell, from Revelations 2.17. “To him that overcometh will I give to eat of the hidden manna, and will give him a white stone, and in the stone a new name written, which no man knoweth, saving he that receiveth it.” And from this text he gave one of the most ingenious, learned and eloquent discourses that I ever heard— The hidden manna, and the white stone, the tessera hospitalitatis he illustrated by historical and critical explanations—with citations of a commentary upon the Medea of Euripides, and an extract from the Poenulus of Plautus. He who overcometh is the Christian conqueror of the world and of himself—the white stone is a compact of friendship formed by Christ with him for Time and Eternity; and the application is to the auditory themselves— There is a diversity of opinion upon the preaching of Mr Bedell— It is highly pleasing to me— His matter is elaborate—his manner thoroughly studied, and his elocution and action, dramatic— But the substance of his discourse is momentous, his doctrines impressive, his delivery solemn, and he leaves altogether an indelible impression upon the memory of his hearers— This afternoon the quarterly meeting of the Sunday School Union was at St. John’s Church— It was opened with a prayer by Dr Laurie— Addresses were made to the Children by Mr Bedell— To the teachers by Mr Milnor and to the auditory by
by Mr Allen. That of Mr Bedell was admirable— Something in the form of a catechism. He gave notice that he should consider himself as being with the children only, and as having no other auditory— He then told the children that he would read to them a verse from the Bible which he wished them all to remember— It was the 9th. verse of the 28th. Chapter of the first Book of Chronicles— “And thou, Solomon my Son, know thou the God of thy father, and serve him with a perfect heart and with a willing mind: for the Lord searcheth all hearts, and understandeth all the imaginations of the thoughts: if thou seek him he will be found of thee: but if thou forsake him he will cast thee off forever.” He commented upon every part of this text, in language entirely suited to the comprehension of the children, and asked them several questions, such as scarcely any of them could be unable to answer— Some one or more of them did in fact answer every question, although this sort of dialogue had not been practiced here, before. Mr Bedell said it was in Philadelphia— I attended again at St. John’s in the Evening, and heard Mr Milnor, from 2. Peter 3.14. “Wherefore beloved seeing that ye look for such things, be diligent that ye may be found of him in peace, without spot, and blameless”— A plain and sensible Sermon— Mr Milnor was formerly a member of Congress from Philadelphia—but is now an episcopal clergyman; settled at New-York. The prayers read were for the 21st. Sunday after Trinity, and the Communion was administered in the morning— I remained to witness, but without taking it— Johnson and Mary Hellen, and John and Abigail went in the Evening, and heard Mr Burnap at the Unitarian Church— Mr and Mrs Frye, and their Son Tom were here at Noon, and I had also a visit from Dr Thornton.

Mrs M’Kinnon is the wife of a Tailor at Baltimore, who came here to solicit a place of Messenger, or any thing else for her husband. I informed her that she must apply to the Heads of Departments for a Messengers Office, and that there was no vacancy to which I could appoint Mr M’Kinnon— Mr Elgar called, and I enquired about the paving of the North side of the square, North of the President’s House— He gave me his reasons for commencing it narrower than that of the adjoining Streets, in a written paper— But the difference being only between 15 and 17 feet, for the sake of uniformity and to accommodate the inhabitants of that vicinity, I told him, I thought it would be best to widen the pavement to the same dimensions with that of the adjoining Streets— He assented; but said it could not then be finished this year. He also observed that there was a similar, and greater contraction of the pavement on the Capitol Square, to that which he had proposed here. I told him I had determined to have a stove put up in this house, similar to those lately built under the Rotunda, at the Capitol; and asked if it could be paid for from the appropriation for the public buildings— He said he was sorry that it could not— I said I would then pay for it from the appropriation for furniture—although it is an expenditure more properly chargeable to the other— Mr Southard brought me a Letter from Commodore Chauncey, with complaints and charges made to him against Midshipman J. Q. A. Boyd— Mr Southard thought there was now no alternative left, but to dismiss him from the service, which I accordingly authorised him to do. Mr Tyler came, and told me he was going to Albany— That he had been obliged to sell his house, and had lost all his property by endorsements and engagements for others— That he was going to pass this winter at the South, and next Spring should seek a Settlement in one of the Northern States— Coll. Jones came with a young man named Hoomes from Virginia; an applicant for an appointment of Lieutenant in the Marine Corps, and who brought with him a number of Letters
recommendatory in his favour— Mr Brent came and took a despatch lately received from Mr Gallatin, stating the substance of a conversation, with Mr Huskisson, relating to the impressment of Seamen— I rode out with my Son John into the woods beyond the Eastern Branch— I found some black walnuts, but no acorns— A herd of swine accounted for their absence— We went over the lower, and returned by the upper Bridge: and came round by the Penitentiary, whence I walked home in 55 minutes— Coll. Trumbull called here this evening; told me his pictures at the Capitol were now finished, and invited me to go and look at them— He took back his model of a Stair-case; and said he should remain here, till after the commencement of the Session of Congress; long enough to ascertain whether they would employ him again—

Mr Montandon came this morning and put up again my Penelope Clock but it stopped again this Evening. He also took my Metallic and my glass thermometers, and my portable brass Sundial to put them in order. Mr. Southard called and left with me Captain Thomas ap Catesby Jones’s Journal of the Cruise of the Sloop of War Peacock, to the Sandwich-Society, and other Islands in the South Sea, in the years 1826 and 1827. The Peacock has recently arrived at New-York, returning from this cruise— I desired Mr Southard to furnish me as soon as he conveniently could with the annual Report from the Navy Department for the preparation of the Message— He said he was occupied already upon it— Mr Clay came in while Mr Southard was here, and Mr Southard jokingly shewed him several Treaties concluded by Captain Jones with sundry Savage kings and Queens in the South Sea Islands— Mr Clay mentioned the application of Mr Rumpf, Minister Plenipotentiary from the Hanseatic Cities of Hamburg, Lubeck and Bremen, for an Audience to deliver his Letter of Credence—for which I fixed to-morrow at one O’Clock— Mr Rumpf comes with Instructions to propose the Negotiation of a Treaty of Commerce between the United States and the Hanseatic Cities— Mr Clay mentioned also the claim of Commodore Rodgers to compensation for his negotiations with the Turkish Capitan Bashaw, during his late Service in the Mediterranean— We concurred in the opinion that the sum of 3000 dollars would be a reasonable and moderate allowance, to be taken from the appropriation for the contingent expenses of foreign intercourse, and to be certified as a secret expense by me— Mr Clay likewise proposed the appointment of Edward W. Clarke as Justice of Peace at the Navy-Yard—and I mentioned to Mr Southard the application of Thomas Fillebrown junr. a Clerk in his Department last Summer, for the same Office. Mr Southard had not heard of the application before, but said he would speak with Fillebrown, concerning it— I walked an hour before dinner, bothered with a shower of Rain.
7. IV:45. Heavy Rain.

Governor Duval came to speak concerning the Settlement of his Accts some items of which have been objected to at the Treasury— They exceed in amount the appropriation made by Congress to cover them, and Mr Rush scruples whether the excess can be paid from the miscellaneous appropriation, because they cannot be included under the denomination of claims “not otherwise provided for.[”] He represented that the expenses had been absolutely necessary and that he had always paid the strictest regard to economy. But one of the items is of 500 dollars for a Clerk to perform the duties of the late Secretary of the Territory, who he said was always absent. Of the present Secretary
M’Carty he spoke favourably—as he did of the appointments of Thomas Randall as judge of the middle District—of Nathanl. Amory as Navy Agent at Pensacola, and of the proposed appointment of Henry Wilson, as Marshal for West-Florida. I told him I would speak with Mr Rush on the subject of his Accounts, and if we found they could be paid from any existing appropriation it should be done. I also conversed with him upon the measures which may be necessary for the preservation of the Live Oak, upon the Public Lands in Florida. He thought with me that there should be a person whose special duty it should be to inspect and superintend them— He says there is much wood upon the grounds, which ought to be taken off; and much waste, and depredation in other places which ought to be prevented. Mr Raguet late Charge d’Affaires at Rio de Janeiro, called, and said he had come to settle his Accounts— He asked me also for a Letter from a friend of his at Rio, to him; which he sent to me the morning that I last left Philadelphia; and I returned it to him— The enclosures he left with me. They are orders from the Brazilian Government to their Admiral Lobo in 1825. not to take neutral vessels for breach of Blockade until after warning. From the date of these orders, immediately after a Note addressed by Mr Raguet to the Brazilian Government, he inclines to ascribe it all to himself— The Letter from his friend that upon the exhibition of these Orders to the Admiralty Court all the captured netural vessels must be acquitted, and Raguet says that the copies of these orders never could be obtained until after he came away— Mr Worthington called for a morning visit; and said he was here in behalf of claimants before the Slave-indemnity Commission. At one O’Clock, Mr Clay came and introduced Mr Rumpff, who delivered to me three Credential Letters from the Senates of the Hanseatic Cities of Hamburg, Lubeck, and Bremen; signed by the Burgomaster President of Hamburg and Lubeck and by the President of the Senate of Bremen. He has the character of Minister Plenipotentiary from the Hanseatic Cities upon a special Mission to negotiate a Treaty of Navigation and Commerce— In delivering the Letters, he addressed to me a very few words, expressive of the desire of the Governments of the Hanseatic Cities, to cultivate the friendship of the United States and their Government; which I answered as briefly by assuring him of our reciprocal feelings; of my own regard for the Hanseatic Republics, and of my determination to foster and promote to the extent of my power our commerical intercourse with them. Mr Clay read me a Letter from Mr Webster written at New York on Monday Morning the first day of their elections for the State Legislature: and he left with me a Letter from W. B. Rochester, also at New-York, of the Evening before— It is apparent from these Letters, that the opposition, under the management of Van Buren, have carried the elections in the City, and throughtout the State— Rochester’s Letter is however remarkable in several other Respects— He urges Mr Clay most vehemently to be a Candidate at the next election for the Vice-Presidency— He declares that if I had been so inconsiderate as to offer him the appointment of Minister Plenipotentiary to the Republic of Colombia, he would have rejected it, and he wants a passage in a public Ship, to go and patch up his Crazy Constitution at Guatemala, till the 4th. of March 1829. He also very distinctly intimates that if I had offered the Plenipotentiary Mission, he should have refused it to remain at home, and be a Candidate for the Office of Governor of New-York next year, because in that event there would have been a possible chance of success— Mr Clay also renewed his complaints against the Postmaster General M’lean, whom he charges with using perfidiously the influence and patronage of his Office, which is very great, against the administration. In these New-York elections it appears that the influence of almost every Officer both of the Custom-house and of the Post-Office has been violently hostile. Mr Barbour made the same complaint, but there is no specific fact mentioned which could be distinctly laid to the charge
of any one— Governor Barbour brought me a bundle of papers relating to the funds held in trust for the Seneca Indians; and Mr Rush an additional document concerning the claim of the Brothers Baring, shewing that Coll. Lane had received credit for the sum in his Accounts— Mr Rush is alarmed for the revenue at a recent great failure in New-York. Mr Potts was a new Solicitor of contributions for the Presbyterian association— This was for aiding in the education of indigent preachers of that denomination. I declined— Wrote to my Son Charles and to R Walsh junr

Mr Thumlert brought me his Letter to Daniel Crommelin and son of Amsterdam, as finally prepared; and he brought with him a German Passport dated 20. April 1772 with which his aunt, and an Uncle older than his father first came to this Country. I undertook to forward his Letter, and in the Evening wrote one to enclose it to C. Hughes. Mr Graham brought a Plat of the Island of Bois Blanc in the Territory of Michigan, with a Letter from the Officer commanding there, recommending the reservation from Sale of about half the Island in Sections coloured on the Plat. I endorsed upon the Plat an order to reserve those Sections from the Sales, for the present— Mr Graham spoke also of his claim of 2 1/2 per Cent for payments in the Settlement of the Affairs of the old office of Superintendent of Indian Affairs. I had not yet mentioned the subject to Mr Rush— Mr Graham left with me a copy of Mr Crawfords order directing the allowance to the Agents— Mr Foy called and informed me, that the ground laid out west of this house for a Nursery of Trees and Plants, was now so far prepared, that the border round it might be planted. I told him my intention of planting a row of alternate acorns and Walnuts, round the whole border—leaving the other spaces for planting the seeds of various other trees domestic and exotic— And he promised to come to-morrow, to commence the planting with me— While he was with me there came a young man from Philadelphia, a nephew of J. Connell’s, with a Letter of Introduction from J. Sergeant, and with an application for the appointment of Commerical Agent at Aux Cayes, for his partner now residing at that place. I referred him to the Secretary of State. Then came Mr Law, with his old argument upon the distresses of the Country; the low price of wheat and tobacco, and the indispensable necessity for paper money. He barely spoke of the plan of finance, which he left with me last Spring. The Slave indemnity Commissioners paid me a visit of form. Mr Browne of the Department of State, brought me two certificates which I signed of monies paid to Commodore Rodgers, for services performed during his late Cruize in the Mediterranean in his intercourse with the Capudan Bashaw, and to the late Daniel Pope Cook upon his mission last Spring to the Havanna. I kept the vouchers, and copies of the Certificates— Governor Barbour brought me a bundle of papers concerning a quarrel between Captain J. L. Smith, commanding Engineer at Fort Macon Beaufort North-Carolina, and a man named Manney, one of the Contractors to furnish bricks—it has proceeded to such extremities, that provocations to a duel appear on the face of the correspondence to have passed between them— The Governor proposed to
to order Smith to another Station, and said he would call again to-morrow— This is the same Smith who was implicated in the affair of Swift, Vandeventer and Mix, and whom Governor Barbour sent to Fort Macon to get rid of him at the Department. Hoomes came to enquire the fate of his application to be appointed a Lieutenant in the Marine Corps— I referred him to the Secretary of the Navy— Mr Elgar informed me that there was an unexpected deficiency in the appropriation for the Penitentiary— That the balance now remaining would be barely sufficient to put on the roof, and that a number of workmen had been employed, who must be discharged unless they could go on, waiting for their pay till another approrpriation shall be made by Congress. This they were willing to do, and they had been engaged with an expectation on their part till the building should be finished. To discharge them at this Season would operate as a hardship upon them; but there was always dissatisfaction in Congress at anticipations upon appropration— He said he could employ them part of the time at the Capitol, which would reduce the encroachment upon the expenditure at the Penitentiary— I directed him to do this; and to keep the workmen employed, though with as little advance upon the next appropriation as possible— I walked before dinner, and stopped to see Mr and Mrs Frye, who have just removed into the old House, which was Mr Hellen’s, and where I passed five winters, when a member of the Senate. Mrs W. S. Smith dined with us. The young Ladies attended an Evening party at Mr Durant St. André the french Consul’s— Signed 3 Land grants of Lots in New-Orleans— Acts of 20. April 1818 and 24. Apl. 1820.

Young Mr Elliot came again this morning to solicit my aid in procuring for him an appointment of Clerk in one of the Public Offices— He said he had seen Mr Clay who treated him kindly; and told him that there was no vacancy in the Department at present— He wished me, to mention his name to Mr Clay in the case of a vacancy occurring, which I told him I would— Mr Brent took back signed by me three answers to Letters of form from kings. One from the Emperor of Brazil, announcing the death of his wife, last January—one from the king of the two Sicilies, announcing the birth of a Son; and one from the king of Sweden, announcing the birth of a second Son, to his Son, Prince Oscar— He took also the papers relating to a question, which has arisen in the Territory of Florida, upon the decease of a Mr Purves, the British Vice-Consul there— A Mr John Inerarity as his Agent, and as Consular Agent authorised by the Consul General Baker, claims possession, not only of all the Official Papers, but of all the effects of the deceased, without giving Bond to the probate judge conformably to the territorial Laws, and Mr Vaughan maintains him in this pretension, by the allegation of a custom. Mr Clay had conversed with me on this subject, and I told him I knew of no such custom; but desired him to consult the Books and ascertain if there was any; and also to call upon Mr Vaughan, for his authority in alledging it. I also doubted our authority to interfere with the operation of the territorial Law regarding the administration of testamentary or intestate estates, though I thought we might write an advisory Letter to the judge to exempt the Official papers and effects from the requisition of Bonds for their delivery— I remarked also upon the singular contrast between this pretension of Inerarity, sustained by Mr Vaughan, in behalf of Consuls, and the practise of the British Government, sustained by the opinions of their Crown Lawyers, exemplified in the case of Mr Gallatin’s Coachman, and which comes very little short of a total denial of all privileged exemption even of Ambassadors, from the operation of the municipal Laws of England. Mr Brent brought me also a Letter from Governor Enoch
Lincoln of Maine, enclosing two depositions relating to the disturbances upon the North-eastern frontier, and purporting also to enclose a Proclamation of his own, upon the same Subject— But the Proclamation was not enclosed— Coll. Roberdeau called to compare the time of the Chronometer here with an observation that he had taken with W. Elliot at Noon— He says that Elliot has made his preparations for taking the observation of the occultations of fixed Stars on the 5th. and 8th of December, recommended in the Letter of Captain Basil Hall. Mr Rush brought me papers, relating to the complaint of Degrand against John Kern, Deputy Collector of the Port of Philadelphia.— There is a written defence of Kern himself, a certificate in his favour, signed by many respectable merchants, and a Letter from the Collector W. Jones, entirely favourable to Kern, and complaining of Degrand— Mr Rush had also a Letter from Mr Wirt, giving information that the causes upon which he had been employed to attend the Circuit Court at Philadelphia, have been continued— Mr Rush brought me also the minutes from the Treasury Department, for the preparation of the Message to Congress— Mr Foy came at four O’Clock as he had agreed: and I planted with him a row of alternate Rock Chesnut Oak acorns, Shag barks and black walnuts, in the border round my enclosure, near the fence— We went only partly round—when some of our nuts failed— We then went to the grounds at the Northern front of the House, where I planted a further number, perhaps a hundred Rock Chesnut Oak Acorns— In the Evening Wyer came and took leave, going tomorrow as a special messenger with Instructions to W. Tudor, Charge d’Affaires at Rio de Janeiro.

Mr Montandon called this morning with the thermometers, and got in order again the Clock which he had repaired, and which had stopped— Mr Lowry the Secretary of the Senate told me he had been about ten days in the city, but the greater part of the time unwell. Samuel Brook, Chief Clerk in the Treasurer’s Office a Quaker came and requested me to receive a visit from a member of that Society whom he supposed to be a Frenchman named Stephen Grolet, but who proved to be an Englishman, named Thomas Shillitoe, and who was accompanied by a friend from New-York named James Brown— Thomas Shillitoe had a Letter of Credence recommendatory, from two Societies, male and female of his own denomination in England, and he gave me a word of exhortation upon two points—one was a solicitation of charity in behalf of two old Indian women, of the Oneida tribe, daughters of a deceased chief named Scenadoah, whom he had met in the Western part of the State of New-York. The other was upon the dreadful vice of intemperance that he had witnessed in the City of New-York, and the check which might be given to it by prohibiting the Sale of spirituous liquors in the grocer’s shops— I told him this was a matter within the exclusive jurisdiction of the separate States— He made some impressive remarks upon the great and increasing prevalence of that detestable vice, and expressed his earnest, apprehension that it would draw down the chastising judgments of God upon the Nation— May they be averted— Mr Clay called while the Friends were here— He spoke of the Letter from Governor Lincoln of Maine, and its enclosures; and he proposed to send a special agent down to the
spot where the disorders have taken place to enquire into and report upon the facts—which I approved— I returned to Mr Clay the Letter from W. B. Rochester which he had lent me, observing that he was mistaken, in supposing that Charles King had my exclusive Confidence in New-York— Mr Brent came to enquire if I had a copy of despatch N. 94. from Mr Poinsett, which had been sent to me at Quincy; the original being mislaid— I found and gave him the copy and also the enclosures— It relates to his Controversy with the Congress of Vera Cruz— General Brown introduced Coll. Morgan, just arrived from the station to which the troops under General Atkinson were ordered to check the hostile movements of the Winebago Indians, which has been effectively done. W Lee came to say that he was going for a few days to New-York. I went out to finish the planting of the row of Acorns and nuts round my enclosure, with Mr Foy—but before completing it, Mr Southard came with a budget of papers relating the business of his Department, to which I gave immediate attention— He took back Mr. Richard S. Coxe’s argument in support of a claim of Messrs.Pottinger and Spence to pay as Pursers in the Navy, during a time when they were not in actual service. I told him that my mind was somewhat undecided upon the merits of the claim, and that I should be glad to consult the members of the Administration concerning it— He had an angry Letter from Mr Burges, one of the members from Rhode Island; urging the appointment of a young man of Newport, whom he had recommended as a Purser; and bitterly complaining that he had not already been appointed; intimating that no appointment could be obtained for a person from Rhode-Island. Mr Southard said that of 32 pursers in the Navy, there were four from Rhode-Island— Her share under no equitable rule of proportion, could amount to more than one: and she had a similar excess of officers of every rank in the Navy, excepting that of Captain, obtained only by regular promotion— I advised Mr. Southard to answer Mr Burges’s Letter by a statement of these facts— Mr Burges is in deep affliction by the loss within these fourteen months of his three daughters, by consumptions; and I fear that his sorrows have affected his temper. Mr Southard spoke of other objects upon the detail of business in his Office, and also of the very unfavourable result of the recent elections in New-York; of which we have this day the first news— He mentioned also the Vice-Presidency, concerning which he had a long conversation with Mr Clay, last Evening. He is strongly averse to Mr Clay’s being the Candidate on the Administration ticket—

Heard this morning Mr Burnap, the same whom I had heard at Medford the 26th. of August last. His text this day was from Ecclesiastes 9.10. “Whatsoever thy hand findeth to do, do it with thy might.” The doctrine he drew from it was that man was made for action: and that all virtue consisted in action— This I believe to be true, generally—though temperance is a virtue rather of omission than of action; and fortitude is rather passive than of action— These are however virtues, the great and immediate operation of which is upon their possessor, in which they may be termed selfish virtues— All social virtue consists in action—in doing good— Mr Burnap’s discourse was ingenious and eloquent, but his delivery is not pleasing. He has acquired more confidence than when I heard him at Medford, which was only his second appearance in the pulpit. His composition is good, and there appears to be no barrenness of thought in his mind— He has received a Call, from the Congregational Society at Baltimore, and is now exchanging for three Sundays with Mr Motte. There is in Smith’s Theory of Moral Sentiments, some disquisition upon this principle that virtue consists in action; with remarks upon the moral perversion of the opposite doctrine, which is one of the dogmas of the Roman Catholic Church—and Smith criticises the sentiments on this subject expressed by Massillon, in a Panegyric upon some Saint— Retirement from the world, and communion with God, are good, only as like sleep to the body, they refresh and fortify the mind for active exertion—
In the afternoon, I heard Mr Baker from Genesis 4.8. “And Cain talked with Abel his brother; and it came to pass when they were in the field, that Cain rose up against Abel his brother, and slew him”— The Sermon was an exposition of that and the two following verses, and the passage upon which he dwelt with the most emphatic iteration was the question what hast thou done?—which he warned all vicious and guilty persons that God would address in the day of account to each of them— I did not go out this Evening.
12. IV:30.— Walk over Tiber

Proud is a black man belonging to Georgetown, who came with Wells a methodist preacher from Baltimore; also black. He brought several recommendatory documents, one particularly from a lodge of York Masons. His object was to obtain a contribution towards enabling him to go to the Colony of Liberia on the Coast of Africa— Dr Watkins came with a Captain Price, from Baltimore; a solicitor for the appointment of keeper of the floating Light at Hoopers Straits— I told him that I believed the appointment was already made, but referred him for certainty to Mr. Pleasonton. Mr Clay took back a draft of a Letter to Mr. Vaughan the British Minister in answer to his, relating to the administration of the effects of Mr Purves the late British Consul in Florida— Mr Clay said he had examined the authorities, and particularly a case decided by Lord Ellenborough in England in 1814. In the Report of which the whole doctrine of Consular privilege was examined— There was no such usage as that claimed for Inerarity in Mr Vaughan’s Letter— Mr Vaughan himself with whom he had held a Conversation, upon the subject, acknowledged that he did not know whether this privilege would be conceded in England, but referred to some case within his personal knowledge, and in which he had understood it to have been allowed in Spain— Mr Clay said he would send me the Book containing the decision of Lord Ellenborough— He spoke also of a draft of an Instruction which he had prepared to send to Mr Poinsett, and of Letters that he had written to Governor Lincoln of Maine and to P. Sprague, one of the Representatives from that State, upon the disturbances on the North-eastern frontier; which I suspect to be a quarrel purposely stirred up to increase the difficulties of the Administration and excite a popular clamour in the Eastern Country against it.— Governor Barbour was also here, and took back the papers relating to the quarrel between Captain Smith, and Mr Manney in North Carolina— I approved of his proposal to order Smith upon another service, to avoid bloodshed between them; but thought Manney was not sustained in his allegations by the Report from General Macomb— Governor Barbour spoke also of the continued adverse intelligence, of the Elections in the State of New-York, and with great discouragement of the Prospects of the Administration— There is a combination against it of all the leaders of the local parties in the State, and the result is proportionably disastrous. He spoke of the Vice-Presidency concerning which he asked my opinion— I observed that it was a matter of much delicacy for me to interfere in at all; but that my own inclination
was for himself— He mentioned that it had been in the first instance proposed to him by Mr Clay—that he wished every personal consideration to be put out of the question; and such person to be selected, as would give most strength to the cause. He thought that this would not be the effect of the nomination of Mr Clay— Mr Foy was here and I finished with him the planting of the border round my enclosure—with Oaks, White, Rock Chesnut, Post, and Willow—Shag barks, Pignuts and Black Walnut—Chesnut, Persimmon, Tulip-tree and Lime— I indulge the imagination and the hope that this border will outlast many Presidents of the United States—but who can look into futurity for the natural life of a row of Oaks? and who can tell how soon they may be uprooted? I asked Governor Barbour for his Report and the Documents from the War Department for the preparation of the Message; but they were not ready— I therefore intermitted this evening my progress upon the draft and answered a Letter received this Morning from George.
13. V. Walk round Capitol Hill

Commodore Tingey came with his Son in Law, Mr Wingate, one of the members elect, of Congress from the State of Maine— Governor Barbour brought me the rough sketch of his Report, upon the State of the War Department, with numerous accompanying documents— He read me the draft of his own Report, and left it with me. He brought also the original proceedings of the General Court Martial, upon the Tennessee Militia-men, at Mobile, in November 1814— These proceedings had been mislaid, and supposed not to be at the War Department— But they have been recently found by the Adjutant General— Governor Barbour suggested the question whether notice should be given in the Newspapers that they had been found— I thought it should, particularly as upon enquirires heretofore for this document the answer had been given that it was not at the Department— Mr Southard expressed the same opinion— Mr Elliot came and proposed to me to view this Evening at his house, the Planet Herschell through the large Telescope of the War Department, to which I agreed. Genl. Bernard and Captain Poussin called, having lately returned, from their Surveys in Florida— Bernard says that the project of a Ship Channel across the Isthmus must be given up as impracticable— That a Steamboat Canal six feet deep is the utmost that could be effected. That there is not more than 19 feet of water on the bar at the Bay of St. Joseph; but that a canal at no great expense may be made between the Bay of Mobile and Pensacola— Edward Chandler is a young man belonging to Georgetown, applying for a Commission as Lieutenant in the Marine Corps. He brought me a Letter of Recommendation from H. Johnson, Governor of Louisiana— Coll. Ogden, Secretary to the Slave indemnity Commissioners, paid a morning visit— Mr Clay brought the minutes I had requested him to make, of the subjects under direction of the Department of State, which it may be proper to notice in the Message— Two or three of them had escaped my attention— He sent me also a despatch that he has drafted to send to J. R. Poinsett our Minister to Mexico— Mr Southard sent for and afterwards returned the papers relating to the Cruise of the Sloop of War Peacock, to the Society and Sandwich Islands, in the South-Sea. He also brought me a List of the names of our Ships of War, with a reference to the naming of the frigate purchased at New-York. By a Law of Congress she must be named from a River of the United States. Johnson Hellen went yesterday to Rockville— John dined this day at Mr Vaughan’s— I walked this morning before breakfast round the Capitol Hill; and went this Evening to Mr Elliot’s and observed the Planet Hershchell, which is in the Constellation of Sagittarius. The sky was not entirely clear— Mr Elliot had the Astronomical Clock from Willard, which I have agreed to take— On my return home, I resumed the preparation of the draft of a Message; in which I made however little progress.
14. V— Walk to Georgetown—

Mr Brackenridge is the District Judge of the United States in West-Florida, and resides at Pensacola— That place was last Summer afflicted with the yellow fever, and his wife went by water to Philadelphia— He himself passed two Months of the Summer at Tallahassee, and left that place about the first of October, proceeding by land to join Mrs Brackenridge, and take her home. He has been arrested by a bilious fever on the road, and gives a dismal account of the sickliness of the part of the Country through which he travelled— He said it was comparable to the yellow fever of the Cities. That he was told that in Twiggs County, Georgia not less than a thousand persons, or a tenth part of the population died last year, and in the adjoining County seven hundred— He spoke also of a Quaker Settlement through which he had passed in North Carolina— And of the contrast in the appearance of their lands, with those all around them cultivated by the labour of Slaves— Thomas Cook was an Englishman, who has been about two Months in this Country, and came to enquire if I could give him a place— He said he had served seven years in the British army; had been in twenty-two Battles, and had been very ill requited. He shewed me an answer from the Office of the Commander in Chief then the Duke of York, to an application from him for half pay or a pension— It was a refusal of both. The half pay because he had not been a commissioned Officer—the Pension because he had not been wounded— He offered to shew me other certificates in his favour; but I told him there were so many applicants Citizens of this Country for every Office at my disposal that I could give him no encouragement to expect one— After he went out Brackenridge said he wondered how they would look, at the public Offices in London, if an American after two months abode in England should go there and ask for a place— Thomas J. Hellen, arrived here this morning; having left Boston, left Saturday— He had returned from Groton, and been readmitted at Cambridge, before taking up his connections there. Coll. Jones the adjutant General, came and took the Record of the proceedings of the Court-Martial, on the Tennessee Militia-men, and read to me his Letter to the Secretary of War, giving an account of the manner in which the document was found— This Letter he proposes to publish in the Intelligencer to-morrow— William Tharp of Missouri sent me a note, and came with a Petition to me, and a copy of a memorial to Congress; complaining of difficulties made by the 3d. Auditor; P. Hagner, and the second Comptroller, R. Cutts, to the settlement of his Accounts as a Suttler to the Army— Governor Barbour came to ask for a decision, on the application from the Militia Officers at Alexandria, for the appointment of Walter Jones as Major General of the Militia of the District, in the place of Walter Smith who has already been appointed— I told him that I did not think the Memorialists had established the superior claim of General Jones, and that I saw nothing in the case which would justify me in reversing what had been done; and so I wished him to answer the applications from Alexandria. My last Visitor this day was a young man from Switzerland, named Tobler, who also came for a place; though he has been only a few months in this Country, and speaks no language but the German— I wasted no inconsiderable portion of this day, in reading a portion of the second Book of the Histories of Tacitus, in the Original and in Gordon’s translation— I say wasted, because it should have been time occupied upon business— I read in the Evening part of the Documents from the War Department, and wrote heavily upon the draft of the Message.
15. V. Sun rose 7:5. Walk to foot of College Hill.

Mr Southard brought me the record of proceedings of a General Naval Court Martial, sitting at Philadelphia, upon the trial of Lieutenant Joshua R. Sands of the Navy, for an assault upon Commodore Chauncey, his Commander; at Brooklyn Long-Island on the 2d. of July last— It was a personal collision and altercation, on a conflict of claim to part of the Navy-Yard, between the United States and Joshua Sands, the Lieutenant’s father, and a mutual setting up, and pulling down of fences. Mr Southard requested my immediate attention to this case, which I accordingly gave. There were three Charges upon all which the Court found Lieutt. Sands gulity, and sentenced him to be cashiered— A majority of the Court in consequence of the peculiar circumstances appearing upon the record of the proceedings, recommend Lieutenant Sands to the Mercy of the President of the United States— I read the papers and subjoined to the Sentence of the Court, the following decision—“The Sentence of the Court is approved, and in consideration of the peculiar circumstances appearing upon the Record, and of the recommendation of the majority of the Court the penalty is remitted.” Mrs. Colvin came to solicit a loan of money, to enable her to purchase a printing Office, for the publication of her weekly newspaper, which I declined. She spoke in a deeply affecting manner, of the incorrigible intemperance of her late husband, and of its consequences, fatal to himself, and so distressing to her. I sent to Mr Hagner the third Auditor, the papers of William Tharp, and requested a Report from him upon the facts of the case— Hagner came, and said that there had been a correspondence between him, and the Committees of the two Houses of Congress to whom Tharp’s Memorial had been referred—a copy of which he would send me, with the Statement of facts— He said every indulgence had been extended to Tharp in adjusting his Accounts, consistent with the indispensable and universally applicable Rules of the Offices— He asked me for the first of two Reports he had made to me, on the claims of T. L. M’Kenney. Governor Barbour called and took the draft of his annual Report with the accompanying documents— Mr Bulfinch introduced Mr Burnap, the young preacher, about to settle at Baltimore. Coll. Roberdeau called to apologise for not going with me Tuesday Evening to Mr. Elliot’s— Major Nourse, brought me a comparative Statement of the Estimates for the Service of the War Department, in the years 1827. and 1828. which I had requested Governor Barbour to send me— Their total amount for 1827. was short of 5,200,000. and for 1828. exceeds 4,800000 dollars— The average is five Millions. Mr Clay introduced Mr Carroll a member of the Senate of New-York, who says he left Albany last Sunday— He is a brother of the young man who was with Mr Clay at Ghent— He said he had an account to settle at the Treasury Department, upon which he found it necessary to appeal to me from a decision of Mr Rush; and asked me when it would be convenient to me to examine the papers— I told him at any time— He confirmed the account of the issue of the Elections for the New-York Elections for the State Legislature, which are in favour of the opposition, almost univerally. Mr Clay left with me, a Note from Mr Rebello, the Chargé d’Affaires from Brazil, with a translation sent by himself, and another made at the Department— Mr Clay said it would require immediate attention, and that he would call concerning it, to-morrow morning. It is in langugae highly offensive; complaining of the partiality of the People of the U.S. against the Emperor of Brazil in his War with Buenos-Ayres; and of Republican intolerance. Mrs W. S. Smith came to stay this day here with her Sister. T. J. Hellen went to Mr Frye’s.
16. IV:45. Market and over Tiber walk.

Dr Wallace of Fauquier County, Virginia, called in the morning and afterwards came and dined with us— He brought with him in a vial, and gave me a small insect yet alive, which he said was the Cicada: and which he had within five days detected upon a locust tree, after a keen search of twenty years. The Doctor published last Summer in the National Intelligencer a descriptive account of the large Cicada, or common Locust, whose noise rings so gratingly in the heat of Summer— Mr Handy came again to solicit an appointment in the Navy for one of his Sons— I referred him to Mr Southard. Mr Clay called and took the Note from Mr Rebello, the Brazilian Charge d’Affaires, and its translations— His opinion was precisely that which I had formed that the Note ought not to be received— It contains rude and offensive Charges of partiality, against the People of the United States, and criminations of Republican intolerance— I advised Mr Clay to see Mr Rebello, to point out the objectionable passages in his Note, and to give him the opportunity to take it back, and alter it so that it could be received. I desired him to suggest to Mr Rebello, that the People of the United States, were the Sovereign authority of the Country— That reflections upon them as a People, by a Minister to their Government, were as offensive, as personal reflections upon the conduct and character of the Monarch, would be from a Minister of the United States to a king or Emperor to whom he should be accredited that all reflections upon the nature of the Government, were in like manner inadmissible. That any complaint against Officers in the Service of the United States, or against any of their Citizens for injury to Brazilians in violation of the Laws of Nations, would be received and duly considered but that if he declined taking back and altering his note; it should be sent back to him; and he should be informed that no answer would be given to it—and a demand should be made upon his Government to recall him— Mr Clay’s views, perfectly concurred with mine— He spoke also of these disturbances in Maine—said he had written to Mr Sprague; and although he did not exactly know what to do further—yet thought something further should be done— I thought the same; and advised that he should address a Note to Mr Vaughan, enclosing copies of the two depositions enclosed in Governor Enoch Lincoln’s Letter, and ask explanations— And that some young discreet Lawyer should be sent into New-Brunswick, to see Baker, the man who has been taken up and imprisoned there, for stopping the British Mail from passing over the land on which he was settled, within the disputed territory— Mr Clay mentioned Mr Barrell of this place—and I approved of the selection— Mr Clay shewed me also a Letter from a friend of his in Virginia, complaining of the Postmaster General’s political movements— Mr Johnston the Senator from Louisiana recommended Dr Davidson as physician of the marine Hospital at New-Orleans— Mr Rush had sent me several Letters of recommendations for him and others—among them a very earnest recommendation by General Brown, of Dr Rice. I spoke to Mr Rush of the further Reports from the Treasury Department, necessary for the preparation of the Message— From the Commissioner of the General Land Office; and from the fifth Auditor— Also the Statement of Estimates for the year 1828— And a Statement of all the Acts of Congress passed at their last Session, referred for execution to the Treasury Department, and of what has been done, under them. All which he promised to have made out as soon as possible— He read me a Letter that he had received from Andrew Stewart, a Representative in Congress from Pennsylvania, urging that internal improvement and domestic manufacturers should again be earnestly recommended
in the Message—but Rush himself concurred in opinion with me, that it would not be advisable, and perhaps not proper. My opinions upon the general subject were given explicitly, in my first Message— Measures of detail should be matured in Congress, and it is time for the President to act upon them, when they are brought to him in the form of bills for his signature— Dr Wallace after dinner went and looked at Mr Pomphrey our Coachman’s eye, which he thinks not entirely lost. The ball however has broken, two Night’s since, after a severe and painful inflammation, with which he has been afflicted since our return from Baltimore. Dr Staughton who attends him pronounces the eye lost. Dr Huntt had doubts. The draft of my Message was this evening suspended.
17. V. Sun rose 7:6. Walk to foot of College Hill.

Mr Montandon brought with him a metallic thermometer, in the form of a watch, with three fingers on three different axes; shewing not only the present temperature at any given time, but the maximum and minimum of heat within the 24 hours—a very ingenious instrument, the main objection to which is that it is of too delicate construction to be constantly exposed to the open atmosphere; and yet can otherwise be of little use— He had also my small portable brass Sun-dial, but said, it could not shew the time accurately—it was an ouvrage de pacotille— But he had not fully discovered the principle of its construction, and did not know the meaning of twelve initial Letters engraved on a loose turning plate between the Circles— I found them to be the initials of the twelve Months, but know not why they were placed there— Mr Montandon had a small parallelogram silver plate, with a slender Needle, which he placed outside of one of my windows, to serve as a Meridian line— Mr Nourse came from the Secretary of War, to ask for the Memorial from the Militia-Officers of Alexandria County, requesting the appointment of Walter Jones as Major General—which was found and given to him— General Brown recommended Dr Rice for physician to the marine hospital at New-Orleans; but I had already directed the appointment of Dr Davidson— Mr Rush brought a Statement from Mr Graham of the proceeds of Land Sales in the current year; and an estimate of those of the next— Also a petition of S. Woods for remission and repayment of a penalty for an excess of nine passengers brought from Ireland, in the Brig Holly, John Studley Master— I examined the papers, and ordered the remission. Mr Rush shewed me the answer he had written to the Letter from Andrew Stewart; upon which I made some observations; and we had further conversation upon the aspect of affairs as they are affected by the result of the recent Elections in the State of New-York— Party organization, and the union of the two men, who controul the movements of the State parties, have triumphed throughout the State; almost without resistance— The consequence is decisive upon the next Presidential Election— But the principles upon which we have acted cannot be overthrown— Mr Clay called with Dr Brockenborough, who is President of the Bank of Virginia— A man by the name of Snelson, an Officer in one of the branches of that Bank, recently absconded; carrying off 42000 dollars in the Bills of the Bank— He has been traced as far as Quebec, where he embarked in a vessel that sailed for Liverpool, only ten hours before the person sent in pursuit of him arrived, to stop him— Dr Brockenborough wished for an application to the British Government, to deliver him up, to be sent home for trial. I saw no reason for declining to make the demand, though it is doubtful whether it will be complied with— There are instances in which robbers of Banks in England have been pursued to this Country, and their plunder recovered from them. Dr Brockenborough mentioned one, of a man at Savannah, who was even taken, and shipped off, without opposition from the people of the place or the Government of the State—but if he could have sued out a writ of
Habeas Corpus, he must have been discharged— Mr Southard read to me the first draft of his annual Report; which he took back to revise, and said I should have it on Monday or Tuesday. It recommends a multitude of Objects; upon which I made some Observations One of them I asked him to reconsider. It was a proposal to increase from 20 to 30 cents a Month the tax upon the wages of the Officers and Seamen of the Navy, for the hospital fund. Mr Bulfinch and Mr Burnap dined with us. Johnson Hellen returned from Rockville— I planted in my Southern Seedling bed, four rows of Post; Willow, White and Rock Chesnut Oak Acorns Chesnuts, Shagbarks, English Walnuts, Persimmon, Tulip-tree and Catalpa seeds; all promiscuously intermixed— My Message Draft is yet suspended— I received Letters from my Sons George and Charles, and partly answered the first.
18. V— Snow.

Heard this morning Mr Burnap from Matthew 5.23— [“]Therefore if thou bring thy gift to the altar, and there rememberest that thy brother hath ought against thee; 24. Leave there thy gift before the altar, and go thy way; first be reconciled to thy brother, and then come and offer thy gift.” The discourse was a continuation of one, delivered before, and which I did not hear— It was a dissertation upon the benefits of public worship— Sensible and eloquent, but in which there seemed to be a connection rather remote between the commentary and the text. In the afternoon I heard Mr Hawley from Revelations 1.17. “And when I saw him, I fell at his feet as dead. And he laid his right hand upon me, saying unto me, Fear not; I am the first and the last: 18. I am he that liveth, and was dead; and behold I am alive for evermore. Amen; and have the keys of hell and of death.”— Mr Hawley considered this text as conclusive demonstration of the Divinity of Jesus Christ—which is indication enough of what he is willing to take for evidence. He read the Evening prayer for the 23d. Sunday after Trinity, and said he had proposed to commence this afternoon a series of discourses, upon the Scriptural Characters of the old Testament who were Types of Christ; and to have considered now Adam in this typical character. But the auditory was so thin that he should postpone this design, till next Sunday— The 13th. Psalm was sung; and not without deep impression upon my mind, and heart— It snowed the greater part of the day, but cleared off cold in the Evening. I arrived, belated at the church and heard only the close of the Sermon— Scarcely enough to know what his subject had been— I took up at Mr Elliot’s, Abigail S. Adams, who had walked with me to Church in the Morning before the Snow began— In the vacant time of the day I read a couple of the Lettres Provinciales, and a few Sections of Murphy’sTacitus. This writer is utterly untranslatable— Murphy’s English is more smooth but his version is not so near to the Original as Gordon’s— It is impossible to convey the meaning of Tacitus without circumlocution and paraphrase; and that must necessarily loose his sententious brevity— I looked particularly for Murphy’s translation of a passage in the History: 2.53—which had struck me much a few days since in the Original— Tacitus says that Licinius Caecina, a new man, lately admitted in to the Senate attacked Eprius Marcellus—ut magnis inimicitiis claresceret: which Murphy translates by saying that Caecina “thought to rise by encountering powerful enmities.”— Gordon has it “that he might by thus declaring enmity against men of great name, signalize his own.” This is much nearer to the thought of Tacitus; but neither of the Translations marks the vivid force of the verb ut claresceret or the full meaning of the words magnis inimicitiis— That he might brighten by great enmities, would be literal but affected—
19. V. Walk before dinner to Kalorama Gate.

Writing to Charles, I had occasion to look into the Lettres Provinciales; and the book took possession of me, from my rising hour till breakfast time; and this was enough to give me a disorderly day— The Snow on the ground deterred me from my early morning walk; instead of which I borrowed the hours between two and four. The Postmaster General, introduced to me Midshipman Drake, son of Dr Drake—of Cincinnati, who is going out in the Delaware Line of Battle Ship, to the Mediterranean— Mr Clay read to me the draft of Instructions which he had prepared for Mr Barrell; whom he proposed to send down in to the State of Maine; and to the Province of New-Brunswick— Also of a Note to Mr Vaughan, the British Minister, enclosing copies of the two depositions, forwarded by Governor Lincoln of Maine— He agreed also to request of Mr Vaughan a Letter of introduction for Mr Barrell, to Sir Howard Douglas, the Governor of New-Brunswick. Mr Clay said he had seen Mr Rebello, the Brazilian Chargé d’Affaires, and told him that the Note which he had recently sent, could not be received— That Mr Rebello had stated that his expressions, being altogether of a general nature, he did not think that exception could justly be taken to them; but Mr Clay told him this could not be suffered even as a subject of discussion— That with regard to complaints against individuals, whether Officers in the Public Service or not, they would receive all due consideration, and the terms in which such complaints might be couched, would be left to the sense of delicacy of the foreign Officer making them— But no paper from a Diplomatic Agent of a foreign State could be received, reflecting upon the body of the People, or the nature of our Government— They must be treated by all foreign Ministers with at least as much respect, as is expected from the Ministers of the United States, to the Monarch and the Monarchy, at the Royal or Imperial Courts to which they may be accredited— Mr Rebello, finally took back his note; but the substitute for it has not yet been received. There were despatches from Mr Shaler, Consul General to Algiers, still in ill health, at Port-Mahon; from Mr Mullowny, Consul at Tangier—and from Mr Brown, our Minister at Paris; with a private Letter also from him to Mr Clay— Mr Brown gives in this Letter his idea of the political morality of the transaction disclosed in the late publications of James A. Buchanan and Philip S. Markley, in the conduct of all concerned; and particularly of General Jackson. His despatch shews that there is too much prospect, that the French Government will give us notice and terminate the Convention of 1822— Mr Carroll brought me the statement of his claim against the Government, as Executor of his father, Register of the Land Office at Franklin, Missouri— He appeals from the decision of the Secretary of the Treasury. I made a rather longer Evening than usual, in my chamber; but my Message draft is still suspended; and this evening like the morning was idled away—partly with Pascal, and partly with Tacitus and his two Translators—Thomas J. Hellen dined with us.
20. V:15. Walk to Georgetown.

The Oil in my glass lamp failed me this morning, and the other giving scarcely light enough to read or write by, I sallied forth and walked to Georgetown with the dawn—returning just as the Sun had risen— Governor Barbour came with his little Son, who was ill, and has just arrived with Mrs Barbour from Virginia. While he was with me, Mr Owen the member of Congress from Alabama came in— He spoke upon the subject of the forfeited Lands in that State and urged the recommendation of a further act of grace to allow time for payment to the purchasers— And he hinted at a cession of the Lands in each State, upon certain Conditions of
payment to be guarantied by the States— I said this so far as related to the Public Lands would bring us back to the condition of the Old Confederation— I said also that there was a proposition made at the last Session of Congress to cede all the Lands to the States within which they were situated— He observed that it was unconditional, and he therefore did not approve of it— He thanked me for the appointment of his brother as Register of a Land-Office in Alabama— Coll. Roberdeau came to inform me that he had brought his two Clocks to go for several days within a quarter of a Second of each other— He proposes to take a meridian observation to-morrow— Mr Johnson came to ask a contribution for repairing Queen’s Chapel so called—a church in this neighbourhood— I received this morning a Letter from R. Walsh junr and went twice for some Volumes of Voltaire’s works, to the Department of State—particularly for that containing the Tale of Le Blanc et le Noir— I took out also a Volume of Buffon’s natural History— I answered Walsh’s Letter in the Evening; which with Voltaire’s Love-letters to Mademoiselle Du Noyer, kept me up till past Midnight—but in the mean time the Message draft continues suspended— The Postmaster General M’lean’s second daughter, Evelina, was married this Evening to a Captain Taylor—Mary C. Hellen, and Abigail S. Adams went to the wedding party— Mrs Adams this day proposed to me that John and Mary should be married this day fortnight—
21. V:45. Sun rose 7:11.— Walk to Meridian Hill.

The weather has set in unusually cold for the Season, and my walk of yesterday and this morning have been pinching. The cold affects also my faculty of writing, and disturbs the order of my attention to my business. Mr Baker the Minister, and Mr Hand, one of the Members of the Presbyterian Church, came and shewed me a Letter of notice from the Cashier of the U.S. Branch Bank here, informing them that the Directors had determined to sell the Church, for the payment of the debt due to the Bank and would buy it in themselves— Mr Baker said the Society were going to make an effort to raise the money, and he himself was going to the North, to solicit contributions. They wished me to give them countenance by heading a subscription list— This I declined, upon the established rule: but observed to them that they knew the state of the debt from the Society to me. The time and manner in which I had advanced the money— The pressing want of the Society, for which it provided, and the promise of repayment to me in quarterly payments of 100 dollars each now nearly two years in arrear, principal and interest— I added that having heavy debts of my own to discharge, I could not in justice to my creditors, go further than I had done for the satisfaction of theirs—excepting; that while they were making their effort to pay their other debts I would so long as I should not be pressed by absolute necessity myself, forbear to press upon them for their debt to me— They acknowledged the failure of the Society in their promises to me; and pleaded their poverty— I observed that the Letter from the Cashier of the Bank was in a very peremptory tone, and as if the Bank had cause of complaint against them. Mr Hand said they had remarked it with surprize; as no dissatisfaction had been manifested by the Bank before. The truth is that this Church like almost every other religious Society in this part of the Country is insolvent Mr Carroll came to enquire if I had examined his memorial— I had, but the papers upon
which it is founded are at the Treasury Department, and must be examined before I can make up a judgment upon the claim— Coll. Jones the Adjutant General, introduced Coll. John B. Walbach of the first Regiment of Artillery— A German by birth; who told me that after having served seventeen years in Europe, he had entered our army, in 1798. and continued in it to this time— He has two Sons whom he wishes also to introduce into the Service, and now applies for a midshipman’s warrant for one of them. I told him I would speak of it to the Secretary of the Navy— I resumed after several days of interval the draft of the Message; by a paragraph respecting our relations with the Brazilian Government— John was out all day shooting— I wrote three short Letters this Evening; and read some Letters of Voltaire’s Correspondence.
22. V:15. Sun rose 7:12. Walk over Tiber.

Governor Duval gave me a Letter, which he has written to me in consequence of remarks he had made to me in Conversation, earnestly recommending the establishment of a judicial District at Thompson’s Island, or Key West— And to this he now added in conversation a recommendation that the place should be fortified. The reasons which he assigned for this were the importance of the harbour in the Event of War: greater in his opinion than that of the Havanna— Mr Clay had sent me the draft of a Commercial Treaty with the Hanseatic Cities of Lubeck Bremen and Hamburg; and spoke of an Article introduced into it copied from one in their recent Treaty with Great-Britain, and referring to an enumeration of the States of Germany, in one of the Vienna Congress Treaties. He thought it would be better to refer generally to the German States, without notice of the Vienna Treaty— I was of the same opinion— Mr Barrell went off yesterday morning upon his mission to Maine and New-Brunswick— Mr Clay sent me also an answer from Mr Vaughan, to his note on the disturbances upon the North-eastern frontier, with several documents relating to the seizure and imprisonment of Baker— This will prove one of the most dangerous of our Breakers— Governor Barbour brought me the annual Report of General Macomb the Chief Engineer, and afterwards sent me the proceedings of an Army Court-Martial, upon the trials of Lieutenants Hunter and Cowan— I had some conversation with him upon the proceedings on the trial of Assistant Surgeon Bryant— Mr Varnum, a Member of Congress from Massachusetts called to pay a visit. Mr Southard introduced Mr Nicklin of Philadelphia, and gave me his annual Report as definitively drawn up— Mr Bailey of Massachusetts, passed two hours of the Evening with me— I continue reading morn and eve, a few Letters of Voltaire’s General Correspondence; which are amusing but absorb more time than I can spare— The Letters of mixed verse and prose are compositions of peculiar character— I recollect none such in any other language than the French— They are lively and pleasing— The versification is regular, but perfectly easy— The only difference between the measured lines and the prose is that the verse has always something of an epigrammatic turn, ending in a point or antithesis. Of these mixed Letters, there are several to the Abbe de Chaulieu to the Prince de Vendome, to La Faye, to Fontenelle, upon a Solar phenomenon, which are very entertaining— Of those in prose, a bitter one in the name of Thiriot, to the Abbe Nadal, and one to the Baron de Breteuil giving an account of his going through the Small-pox, are among the most interesting— His Love-Letters to Mademoiselle Du Noyer, are ardent, and shew a Spirit of intrigue, deep enough for a youth of twenty; but many of his subsequent Letters to Ladies, are grossly indelicate, though adapted I suppose to the state of morals at the Court of the Regent-duke of Orleans— He is constantly complaining of sickness—yet living most of his time in Solitude and writing prose and verse, without intermission.
23. V:45. Sun rose 7:13. Walk to Meridian Hill

The cold weather continues— My fingers refuse the office of writing at my rising hour, and are benumbed with cold when I return from my walk before breakfast— Mr Brent called for the papers relating to the North-Eastern boundary quarrel which with others I sent back to the Department of State— Mr Clay who has been unwell is convalescent. He took with him the draft of a Treaty with the Hanseatic Republics of Lubeck, Bremen and Hamburg, upon several Articles of which we had free conversation.
