Major Nourse brought me the proceedings of a Court of Enquiry, upon Charges brought by Assistant Surgeon Bryant against Assistant Surgeon Beaumont— Mr Rush had some additional papers from the Treasury, wanted for the preparation of the Message— He was earnest for the reduction of the Estimates of the several Departments for the service of the year 1828 to the lowest sum, absolutely needed.— I expressed some doubt whether it might not be advisable to present them with some margin for the economists in Congress, to plume themselves upon paring down— The Committees of Ways and Means and of Finance, are often influenced by this Spirit— They think they must retrench something from the Estimates presented to them—and if some superfluity is not given them to lop off, they will cut into the very flesh of the public necessities— Mr Rush said that by Letters received yesterday from the Collectors of Boston and Philadelphia, he should be obliged to reduce by 300000 dollars his estimate of the receipts into the Treasury during the present quarter. For this we found it difficult to account, though I observed that by a statement in a Boston Newspaper, which I shewed him there appeared to have been in the third quarter of the present year an extraordinary excess of exportations, and consequently of drawbacks, over those of the corresponding quarter of the year 1826— There came a man, who said his name was George Washington Green, of Baltimore: that he had shaken hands with me at Baltimore when I was last there. That he had worked hard for me there. That he had been formerly an officer in the army— That he came from Baltimore yesterday upon some business— Had lost his pocket-book containing all his money. That he did not like to beg; but wanted money to get home, and had been advised to come to me— I told him that I did not know him; and thought he should apply for aid to those who did— Mrs Smith dined with us— I had some conversation this Evening with John; wrote a paragraph or two in the draft of my Message; and read a few Letters of Voltaire.
24. V:15. Sun rose 7:14.

Mr Montandon came and fixed the small silver plate with the meridian line at my window, but did not effectually put in order my Penelope Clock. Mr Barton, the Senator from Missouri paid me a morning visit— He said little upon political subjects, but like every other person friendly to the Administration, expects a Session of Congress unexampled in factious violence and fury. My own mind is made for it; and I have only to ask that as my day is, so may my strength be.

lg.l: Celui qui met un frein à la fureur des flots
Sait aussi des méchans arreter les complots.

div.p:
Mr Rush brought me the general table of Estimates for the year 1828: the Report from the Commissioner of the Land-Office, and a corrected estimate of the receipts at the Treasury for the present year— He afterwards sent me the
papers relating to the claim of Mr Carroll, who called again to enquire if I had decided upon it; but before I had received the papers— Mr Carroll who is a member of the Senate of New-York now in Session, said he proposed to leave the City on Monday or Tuesday; and that if I should not before then come to a decision upon his claim, he should leave it in the hands of his brother— Coll. Roberdeau called to give me the time from his Meridian obeservation this day with Mr William Elliot. He spoke also of a Memoir that he has been preparing upon the organization of the Militia—an object that he has greatly at heart— Coll. Jones came with a Memorial to me, from I. B. Crane, Major by Brevet, of the fourth Regiment of Artillery, claiming another Brevet Promotion, upon the precedents of Brevets to several Officers of the Marine Corps—for ten years Service— Coll. Jones had much to say on the subject of Brevets; and left with me a minute, recomending the establishment of a Rule, that the authority to confer Brevet Rank on officers of the Army, who shall have served ten years in any one grade, under the act of July 6. 1812. should be restricted to the commissioned Officers who served as such during the late War with Great Britain— He thought this had been the intention of Congress in passing the Act— He also left with me a printed copy of the order of General Brown, of 12. October 1827. for changing the Stations of the Artillery Regiments—which is announced as the commencement of a system— Biennial Exchanges; between the sickly, and the healthy Posts. Mr Baldwin the Engineer was here—going on to Norfolk. He gave me some account of the progress of the works for the dry Docks at Charlestown. Mr Southard called to take back his Report for a final revision; but left it with me till Monday— Mrs Frye and Mrs W. S. Smith were here in the Evening— John dined at the Minister from the Netherlands Huygens; and Abigail S. Adams went to Judge Cranch’s— I received a Letter from Charles, and neglected the draft of my Message.

Heard Mr Burnap this morning from John 20.31. “But these are written, that ye might believe that Jesus is the Christ, the Son of God; and that believing ye might have life through his name.” The argument of the Discourse, was the position of the text; that John’s Gospel was written to induce the belief of the disciples, that Jesus was the Christ—the Son of God—and that this belief should be to them the pledge of immortality. He dwelt upon the character of John; upon his intimacy with Jesus—upon the force of his testimony, and upon the weight of this express declaration of the purpose for which his gospel was written— This was indirectly an unitarian Sermon— The inference from simple reason is that the Son of God cannot be God himself— That the Christ, the Messiah, the anointed, the king of Israel, is and must be subordinate to the Deity— In the afternoon, Mr Hawley read prayers at St. John’s Church, for the 24th. which this year is the last Sunday after Trinity. He preached from 1. Corinthians 15.22 “For as in Adam all die, even so in Christ shall all be made alive.” It was the first of the promised series of discourses upon the characters of the old Testament, considered as Types of Christ— He ran a parallel between the disobedience of Adam, and the perfect obedience of Christ, and between their respective consequences the ruin and restoration of the whole human race— And he gave notice that the next Sunday he should consider the typical character of the sacrifice of Abel— In the Evening I heard Mr Burnap again from Psalm 4.4. “Commune with your own heart.” upon the advantages of religious meditation— The two Tayloe’s called with Dr Thomas a young physician from Maryland lately settled here— Abigail S. Adams returned this Evening from judge Cranch’s— I resumed the draft of the Message, and left unfinished my answer to Charles’s Letter. The weather is cold and cheerless— I wasted some time upon Voltaire’s general Correspondence, and upon his life by Condorcet, which does not please me— The Correspondence loses much of its interest because it gives only Voltaire’s Letters, and none of those from his Correspondents to which his own are answers or replies— Tis like half a pair of Scissors.
26. VI:15— Walk over Tiber

Mr Mitchell came to solicit a subscription for a periodical work called the Spirit of the old dominion— Governor Barbour was here, and I gave him the Letter of Resignation of Leonidas Polk, brevet 2d. Lieutenant of Artillery, and late a Cadet at West-Point— Governor Barbour spoke of a recent publication in Ohio, of a Letter of Thomas M. Randolph, upon the opinions of Mr Jefferson, relating to the late Presidential Election, and proposed to me the publication of his Letter to my father, on that subject, which I declined— I said I had not the Letter here, but that if I had, I would not publish it—possessing it only as my father’s Executor, and it having been confidential— That the Executors of Mr Jefferson’s Will undoubtedly possess a copy of the Letter, and as the depositaries of his confidence are the only persons who can with propriety authorise its publication— He said he had written about it to T. J. Randolph, but had received no Answer— Morning visits from N. Amory, appointed Navy Agent at Pensacola, Mr White the Delegate from Florida, Colonels Jones and House, and Captain Downes of the Navy, who is going to Norfolk, to take command of the Line of Battle Ship Delaware, going out to the Mediterranean— Mr Carroll came again to enquire if I had decided upon his claim, but I had not received the papers— They were sent me late this Evening by Mr Rush— Mr White asked concerning the appointment of a Marshal in West Florida— I told him I had fixed upon Henry Wilson; though his Commission had not yet issued— Mr Brent took some papers belonging to the Department of State— I sent for Mr Pleasonton, to direct the appointment of Joseph B. Hinton as keeper of a floating Light at Ocracoke, North Carolina; but Pleasonton informed me, that this man, a Methodist Preacher, and hot electioneering partizan, upon both which capacities he values himself in his importuning Letters to me, is a debtor to the United States, for 1500 dollars received nine or ten years ago, as Clerk of a Court, and never paid over, which seems a Checkmate upon Mr Hinton’s floating light keeping— Mr Rush read to me his annual Report upon the finances which he has already prepared— It is very long; very well written; and enters largely into the discussion of the policy of encouraging and protecting our domestic manufactures. It will of course be roughly handled; in and out of Congress— But the policy that it recommends will outlive the blast of faction; and abide the test of time. Mr Bailey called while Mr Rush was here to enquire if a Surveyor had been appointed at North Kingston Rhode Island. He had recommended a Mr Hall—but the appointment had been suspended at the request of D. J. PearceMr Clay also called, and took back a draft of a Letter he had written to Governor Enoch Lincoln of Maine— I advised him to modify it, so as to avoid all the expressions which might be personally offensive— Lincoln’s own Letters are absurd, and provoking— And he is deeply infected with a disease which many of the Governors of the States, are apt to catch—wanton assailing of the General Government— Overweening zeal for the interests of the State, stimulated by the Ambition to brighten by the magnitude of their enmities— Mr Clay spoke also of a Note from Mr Vaughan complaining of a Law of the State of New-York, giving to the local magistracy, authority in cases of administration upon the effects of deceased foreign Mariners, and seeming to intrench upon
the Consular jurisdiction— Mr Clay had likewise a Letter from Joseph B. Hinton, similar to those I have received from him— Mr Frye was here great part of the Evening, and spoke of my advances on account of Thomas J. Hellen; which he proposes to pay by instalments.
27. V:30. Walk to Meridian Hill.

Mr Southard came and took back his Report, to give it a finishing hand. Mr Matthews to introduce Mr Evans who is President of a College at Emmetsburg in Maryland. Major Nourse took away the Report of General Macomb— Mr Carroll came while I was in the midst of his papers, which are numerous— He told me he should go to-morrow, and complained, bitterly of the delays in the transaction of business with the Treasury Department— Coll. Roberdeau introduced Dr Swift, an assistant Surgeon in the Army, recently arrived from a voyage upon the late dislocation of the troops— They met with a dreadful gale, in the gulph-Stream, and he says were only saved by throwing out an Anchor with a hundred fathom cable, without bottom—an expedient suggested at the last extremity of danger by a Soldier, who had been a Sailor, and said he had been saved by it once before. Dr Swift says it saved them by bringing the head of the vessel to the wind— Mr Crocket is a new member of Congress from North-Carolina, who was introduced to me by Mr Williams— They travelled through Richmond, where they were informed that Andrew Stevenson was to be the opposition candidate for Speaker, at the approaching Congress— Governor Barbour brought a Letter from John Forsyth the new Governor of Georgia, complaining of a robbery and a murder committed by Indians in that State; and a Letter from T. L. M’Kenney of the 17th. instt. from Milledgeville, stating that he had concluded a Treaty with the Creek Indians, for the cession of all the remnant of their Lands within the State of Georgia— Mr Wirt, the Attorney General called—just arrived from Balitmore. I requested him as I had the other members of the Administration to come at One O’Clock to-morrow, and hear the draft of the Message— I finished it this day— It has been written under such agony of mind, proceeding from causes relating both to public and private affairs, that I am ashamed of it—and almost afraid to read it to my confidential advisers— Captain Downes and Mr Nathanael Amory dined with us— Mr White, the Delegate from Florida, came to recommend a Mr Bryan as Marshal for West-Florida— I had directed a Commission to issue for Henry Wilson— I told White that I had consulted Governor Duval upon this appointment; and he had recommended Wilson. He said he had no objection to make against Wilson; but that Bryan would give much more satisfaction to the People— That Governor Duval himself was in a very small minority in the Territory. It had been said that he, White, would remonstrate, against the reappointment of Duval as Governor— That was not his intention. But there would be a strong remonstrance against it from the Inhabitants of the Territory— There was no dissatisfaction with the appointments of the General Government there— Mr M’Carty, in particular, the new Secretary was universally esteemed— I told Mrs Adams this morning that I could not consent to the marriage of John with Mary Hellen at this time— She went out to Rossburg— Mr and Mrs Frye, and John, went out there afterwards, but she concluded to return to the City to-morrow— Mrs W. S. Smith, passed the day here. This day and yesterday have been burdens to existence to me; and they are preludes to days of yet infinitely severer trial. In the midst of the most exquisite distress the performance of my public duties has afforded me some relief— But a mind distracted with grief, and with terror for one most tenderly beloved, is ill suited to the composition of State Papers, to the investigation of intricate claims, and to the cheerful entertainment of friends at the hospitable board— To all this I have been this day called; and if I have not sunk under it, may he who has sustained me now, prepare me for his further will, and bear me up, at my utmost need—
28. V:15.— Walk round house Square.

The members of Congress are fast coming in; and I had this day visits from Mr Noble, the Senator, and O. H. Smith a new member of the House of Representatives from Indiana; and from T. R. Mitchell of the House from South-Carolina— Smith of Indiana comes in the place of Dr Test— A Mr Dean of New-York, came with an Indian named Dick, and delivered to me two Petitions, one from the Stockbridge Tribe of Indians, residing at Green Bay and the other from the Brothertown Tribe, including the remains of the former Mohegan, Montauk, Narragansetts, Pequots and Nahantick indians, against a Treaty concluded last Summer, by Governor Cass and Thomas L. M’Kenney with the Winebago and Menominie Tribes, and wherein the Peitioners say that Lands which rightfully belonged to them were ceded to the United States without their consent— I told Mr Dean that I would give due attention to the Petitions, but that he must apply to the Secretary of War for the decision upon them— Tippet applies for any small Office; but I have none to bestow— He said he was in great trouble. Hilliard is returning home to Boston, from Virginia, where he has been for several weeks— He said there was a difference of construction at the different Custom-Houses, of the impost duty upon foreign books published before 1775.—at Boston and New-York, the duty was levied of 16 cents the pound weight; and at Philadelphia, only four Cents the Volume: which he observed made on a folio Volume weighing 25 Pounds the difference of four cents from four dollars—and the duty by weight amounted often to more than the cost of the book itself— I advised him to speak of it to the Secretary of the Treasury— At one O’Clock there was a meeting of the Members of the Administration; and I read to them my draft of the Message— Very few Observations were made upon it— And no objection was made to any part of it— Some additional paragraphs were spoken of as perhaps expedient—and particularly one relating to the State of Affairs with Georgia, and the Creek Indians— This I had postponed, waiting for the arrival of Mr M’Kenney who Governor Barbour said had reached Baltimore, and was to be here to-morrow— Mr Clay remarked upon the view taken of the established system concerning the Public Lands; which he thought correct, though there were parts of the Country where it would not be approved— But as I had recommended the revival of the Law of May 1826. for the relief of purchasers on credit, he thought it might be advisable to add another recommendation, remitting forfeitures actually incurred; at least under certain guards and restrictions. There was also a paragraph upon the Madawaska War, of the expediency of which he expressed some doubt— Mr Rush noticed the detailed exposition of internal improvements, which I was myself inclined to abridge— I had presented a Summary of the Recommendations in the Report of the Secretary of War, but of those in the Report of the Secretary of the Navy, had noticed only that of the Naval Academy— Mr Southard remarked this difference, with some sensibility. They took the draft of the message; to examine it to-morrow at a meeting among themselves— Mrs Adams returned from Rossburg—with Mrs Frye—dined with her and came home this Evening. Mrs Smith passes the Night here. Governor Barbour brought me a Note from Coll. R. Jones the Adjutant General, upon the trial of the Assistant Surgeon Thomas S. Bryant— The proceedings in that case appear to be irregular. The Court at first consisted of five members who decided against their own jurisdiction upon the Charges. General Scott sent them back to the Court, and added two Members who changed the majority, and reversed the prior decision— No precedent has been found to warrant this measure on the part of Genl. Scott— The authorities appear to be against it.
29. VI.— Walk to Kalorama— Rain

Mr Taylor, Speaker of the House of Representatives at the last Congress called this morning, having arrived yesterday— The opposition have been encouraged by the complexion of the Elections to the House, to begin the War in Congress against the Administration, by electing a Speaker of their own party; and in several of their Newspapers in various quarters of the Union, they have urged their men to make a point of being here some days before the commencement of the Session; which they are accordingly doing. The result is extremely doubtful; and depends upon the votes of members from his own State—some of whom are among the most inveterate against him— He gave me the first information that H. W. Conway, the Delegate from the Territory of Arkansas, has been killed in a duel, with the Secretary of the Territory Crittenden, who was also badly wounded— General Van Rensselaer also paid a morning visit; and Mr M’Kenney, just returned from his missions to the Indians, and who said he would call again— We had a Diplomatic company to dine; with the members and Secretary of the Slave Indemnity Commission—Anthony St. John Baker, and Miss Baker his Sister, Mr Bankhead, L. Cheves, Doyle, Mr. Durant Saint André, and Madame, Mr and Mrs Hersant, Chevalier Bangeman Huygens and Madame, Prince Lieven, Mr Lisboa, Baron Maltitz and MadameCount de Menou, Coll. Ogden, Mr Pleasants, Mr Ouseley, Mr and Mrs Rumpff, Mr Seawell, Mrs Shaw, Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith, Baron Stackelberg, and Mr Vaughan— Mrs Adams and all the family also dined at the table— Mrs Shaw is a widow, and daughter of General Nathanl. Green, the Revolutionary warrior. She has recently returned from France, where she had been spending some Months at General La Fayette’s, and brought me a Letter from him. Mr Pleasants and Mr Seawell had some conversation with me on political affairs— Both avowing friendly dispositions.
30. IV.— Rain—

The Rain continued through the Night and all this morning. The weather cleared off this afternoon and I walked an hour before dinner. Mr Graham brought me a Report upon the Sales of the Choctaw School fund Lands— He took back his general Report on the Sales of Public Lands, and accompanying Statements, and afterwards sent me two copies of it, to be communicated to Congresss with the Message. The members of the Administration were here from one till three O’Clock: having examined it yesterday among themselves— I had requested them particularly to mark passages for retrenchment; wishing to shorten the paper, which is too long. They did accordingly propose several omissions, all judicious, and some verbal alterations, all which I approved. I determined also to strike out, one or two passages upon which there was a difference of opinion among them, as to the retaining or excluding them; and I added one short paragraph at the suggestion of Mr Clay— The paragraph upon the Report of the Postmaster-General, was much objected to— This Officer who came into that place in 1823, has given great satisfaction in the Administration of it— For three or four years before, it had been a burden upon the Treasury, requiring annual Appropriations of nearly a hundred thousand dollars a year— Its condition since then has been constantly improving, and this year the receipts exceed the expenditure more than a hundred thousand dollars— The accomodations to the public, and the facilities in the transportation of the mail have at the same time been multiplying in like proportion— Mr M’leans Report is not backward in setting forth all these improvements and my paragraph in restating the facts upon which he celebrates his own efficiency, did him ample justice— But as respects the Administration, Mr M’lean’s conduct is worse than equivocal— He hates Mr Clay, and is devoted to Calhoun, to whom he justly gives credit for his appointment, first as Commissioner of the
Land-Office, and afterwards as Postmaster General. Before the last Presidential Election, Mr M’lean was professedly favourable to me—but under Calhoun’s influence, and secretly inclined in favour of Jackson. His conduct since the election has been at variance with his professions. To me he has protested the most friendly disposition to the Administration and to myself; but he has placed in the Post-Office persons of infamous character, tools of Calhoun; his appointments of Postmasters, and his management of contracts are said to be insidiously partial to the opposition; and his conversation is marked with a Spirit of hostility exceedingly offensive to the friends of the Administration— He is accordingly courted by the Opposition, and keeps on the best terms with them— This was the main reason which induded Governor Barbour to object to my paragraph upon the Post-Office, which he thought too complimentary to Mr M’lean, and he thought importing some censure upon his Predecessor— I abridged a little the paragraph on the Post-Office, and made every other alteration proposed by them— Governor Barbour brought two additional paragraphs to his report one relating to the Ordnance Department and the Lead mines— The other to Coll. M’Kenney’s indian negotiations— There was some Conversation upon the question of boundary between the State of Georgia and the Territory of Florida—upon which I had received a Letter, documents and a Map from Governor Forsyth— Governor Barbour said the claim of Georgia was preposterous; but thought that if I should notice it to Congress at all, it should be in a separate message— I gave the amended message to John, to make out two Copies of it, for the two houses of Congress next Tuesday. There was a Stranger from New-York, whose name I have perhaps not correct, and three from Maryland, names unknown, who came to see the President’s House, and the President. Mr Martindale of New-York was here an hour this Evening. He was extremely desirous that I should introduce into the Message, an earnest recommendation of protection to domestic manufactures. He said that my sentiments upon the subject were misrepresented in the Western part of New-York. That it was pretended I had never expressed any Sentiment favourable to the manufacturing interest— I told him that the friends of the Administration in the South, were equally urged that nothing should be said upon the subject, and on full deliberation I had concluded that would be the safest course— Particularly as to take side prematurely, would appear to interfere improperly for the purpose of exercising an influence over the house— I added however that the Report of the Secretary of the Treasury upon the finances would with my entire approbation recommend the protection of the manufacturing interest, in the most effective manner— I examined this evening the papers relating to the claim of Charles H. Carroll; and began writing a decision upon it.

Day. My intention is to rise at five O’Clock—but I have not been able to accomplish it. My average time of rising is half past five; and the range is from four to near seven— I write till after Sunrise—then walk an hour—breakfast and from ten till five in the afternoon receive visitors, read newspapers and transact business. Dine between five and six, and pass the Evening from seven till eleven in my chamber usually alone; reading and writing— The draft of my message has occupied part of almost every evening; and I have written a few Letters— I have also read part of a Book of the History of Tacitus— The Provincial Letters; half a Volume of the Correspondence Generale of Voltaire, and part of the Memoirs of his Life— This reading is so entertaining that it absorbs too much of my time— It is however a great drawback upon the interest of the Correspondence that the Letters of the Correspondents are not given— There is much flattery, and much selfishness in Voltaire’s Letters— A warm disposition to serve his friends, and yet a frequent disposition to speak slightingly of them— His industry is admirable.
